title: 11 Foods That Will Actually Detox Your Body, According to Experts
author: Michele Promaulayko
description: Sometimes you need to give your body's natural detox process a boost, and these nutritious (and delicious) foods will do just that.
cleaned_text: 11 Foods That Will Actually Detox Your Body, According to Experts Whether or not you realize it, your body is naturally detoxing all the time, without any nudging—and not just when it's [sweating out](https://www.eatthis.com/weight-loss/) the remnants of Tequila Tuesday during a brutal Wednesday-morning workout. You have many detoxification systems that recruit various organs, including your skin, lymph nodes, brain, kidneys, and liver. (For a primer on the two-step detox process, [read this](https://www.the-well.com/editorial/how-the-body-detoxifies-naturally).) When Your Detox System Needs A Jumpstart Even though detoxing happens naturally, there are times when you can benefit from helping it along, such as after the aforementioned night of boozing or when you need a reset after indulging in too many sugary or processed foods. It's also a good idea to encourage your body to remove the environmental toxins (pesticides, household chemicals) we touch, inhale and ingest on a daily basis and that accumulate in our tissues and cells. Alarmingly, as [one study indicated](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/18075624/), many of these toxins have demonstrated harmful effects, including cancer, reproductive, metabolic, and mental health effects. Signs your detox system may need a helping hand: You're experiencing digestive issues, headaches, skin problems, mood swings, brain fog, nausea, and fatigue. Whatever you do, [don't resort to these detoxing methods](https://www.eatthis.com/detox-tips/). Instead, try the following foods to help support your inborn clean-up crews: Artichoke Leading medical herbalist Healing](https://urbanhealingnyc.com/pages/about), notes that artichokes "stimulate the function of the liver so they are hepatoprotective and enhance the production of bile." These actions have been [widely studied](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/26310198/), and "artichoke leaf extract is a registered medicine in Europe," says Turley, who recommends [artichoke leaf tea](https://www.wellandgood.com/artichoke-tea/) as a convenient way to incorporate the benefits into your diet. Find more [detoxifying teas here](https://www.eatthis.com/news-best-detoxing-teas/). Lemon In Ayurveda, sipping warm lemon water in the morning helps jump-start your "agni," or your digestive fire—and that "heat" is thought to be purifying. Lemons are also a [good source of vitamin C](https://www.eatthis.com/benefits-of-lemon/), which can help the body protect itself from damaging free radicals. For 20 amazing ways to use lemons (beyond just upgrading your water), read [this](https://www.eatthis.com/uses-for-lemon/). Ginger [Ginger](https://www.eatthis.com/health-benefits-ginger/) is an age-old treatment for digestive health. "The most pharmacologically active compound in ginger is called gingerol, which favorably impacts the gastrointestinal tract," [Ali Webster, Ph.D., Not Ginger's high level of antioxidants also [help kidney function](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/22017619/), the detox process. [Dr. Josh CNS, a clinical nutritionist, recommends [this detox drink](https://draxe.com/recipes/secret-detox-drink/), which contains lemon juice, apple cider vinegar, cinnamon, ginger, and cayenne pepper. Cucumbers Cucumbers are not only packed with a plethora of vitamins and nutrients, but they're made up of about 96% water, making them a great way to hydrate while snacking. Because dehydration can cause constipation, cucumbers help support regularity with their high water content and [levels of pectin](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/25623312/) (a soluble fiber). Dandelion Greens While you may consider dandelions a pesky weed (you're not wrong), they're also incredibly nutritious, with a long history in traditional herbal medicine. Besides being packed with vitamins and inflammation-fighting antioxidants, dandelion greens may help [protect the liver from toxic substances](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/22424457/) and stress. Plus, they're [ a natural diuretic](https://www.eatthis.com/diuretics/) so they'll help flush out excess fluids. Though they are among the most [underrated salad greens](https://www.eatthis.com/lesser-known-salad-greens/), you can find them in Mediterranean restaurants, and you can find them as detoxifying teas, too. Coffee Coffee-lovers rejoice! This beloved beverage is one of the best drinks for liver health. Numerous studies have shown that coffee can [lower the risk of cirrhosis](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/24199670/) and of [developing liver cancer](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/25291138/). This may be in part because coffee [helps prevent fat from building up around the liver](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/25291138/). If you're looking for a stellar cup of Joe, we've tracked down [the best in every state](https://www.eatthis.com/best-coffee-state/). Cordyceps Mushroom Cordyceps, a genus of parasitic fungi, has been used for centuries in Traditional Chinese Medicine to treat health ailments. "Cordyceps has been [shown in clinical trials](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/25519252/) to improve kidney function, even in kidney disease," says Turley, who educates about the medicinal properties of plants on her [Instagram feed](https://www.instagram.com/urbanhealingnyc/?hl=en). Why not combine the benefits of coffee and cordyceps with this mushroom coffee from [Four Sigmatic](https://us.foursigmatic.com/products/mushroom-coffee)? Beets These earthy root vegetables (also known as beetroot) are packed with nutrients and fiber—one cup of raw beets has [3.8 grams of fiber](https://www.eatthis.com/what-are-beets/)! "They are well-known to be vasodilators, helping to increase blood flow, which helps blood pressure, brain function, and athletic performance," Chloe Paddison, the registered dietitian behind [Cureative Nutrition](https://www.cureativenutrition.com), told [Eat This, Not That!](https://www.eatthis.com/what-are-beets/). Never screw up roasting beets again by [following these instructions](https://www.eatthis.com/roasted-beets-recipe/). Prickly Pear Prickly pear, a type of edible cactus, is often used for its fruit juices—and may just be your next hangover cure! [This study](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/15226168/) found that those who consumed prickly pear extract before drinking alcohol had less severe hangover symptoms. This could be because it helps [maintain antioxidant and inflammation levels](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/23047946/). Learn how to find and prepare this exotic fruit [here](https://www.thespruceeats.com/prickly-pear-cactus-fruit-2343047). Crunchy Veggies Cruciferous veggies—like broccoli and Brussels sprouts—are two more detox-friendly foods to add to your plate. Both have been shown to [increase the liver's detoxification enzymes](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/20722931/), aiding in the detox process while also [protecting the liver from damage](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/21535814/). Here are [5 best Brussels sprouts recipes](https://www.eatthis.com/brussels-sprout-recipes/) that you're sure to love. Turmeric Curcumin, the active ingredient in turmeric, has been shown to [help liver function](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6073929/#:~:text=Their%20result%20showed%20that%20curcumin,could%20be%20measured%20%5B70%5D.) by flushing out toxins and providing a boost in [antioxidants that help repair cellular damage](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/17569207/) done by free radicals.
